caseTitle: CONTRIBUTION OF JUSTICE TAYLOR TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF GHANA L
summary: In Nkrumah v Manu (1970), Justice Kobina Taylor, then a High Court judge, delivered a landmark decision that challenged binding precedent and technical legalism in favor of substantive justice. The case involved a slander claim where the district magistrate awarded damages mislabeled as 'special damages.' Taylor refused to overturn the decision on this technical ground, criticizing undue reliance on form over substance. He re-examined the choice-of-law rules under paragraph 64 of the Courts Decree, 1966 (NLCD 84), rejecting the earlier Court of Appeal decision in Attiase v Abobbtey, which had ignored statutory changes. Taylor held that the applicable law must follow the statutory framework, requiring a plaintiff to explicitly claim customary law application. His analysis, though initially controversial and criticized by some judges, was later vindicated by the Court of Appeal in Kyei v Donkor, which endorsed his interpretation. This case established Taylor’s judicial philosophy: a purposive, policy-oriented approach that prioritizes justice over rigid precedent.
verdict: The appeal was dismissed. Justice Taylor upheld the award of damages despite the incorrect label of 'special damages,' emphasizing substance over form and applying the correct statutory choice-of-law rules under NLCD 84.

rationaleHighlights: Refusal to allow technical mislabeling of damages to defeat justice
Statutory repeal of old choice-of-law rules rendered prior precedent obsolete
Binding precedent followed per incuriam may be lawfully rejected
Explicit election required for customary law application under NLCD 84
Critique of appellate decisions ignoring statutory changes
Emphasis on justice, fairness, and policy over formalism
Subsequent judicial endorsement of Taylor’s position in Kyei v Donkor
Assertion of judicial independence at the High Court level
